chapters.name: MOTION IN A STRAIGHT LINE
chapters.prerequisites: Basic knowledge of mathematics and physics fundamentals

topics.name: INTRODUCTION TO MOTION
topics.context: Motion is common to everything in the universe. We walk, run and ride a bicycle. Even when we are sleeping, air moves into and out of our lungs and blood flows in arteries and veins. We see leaves falling from trees and water flowing down a dam. Automobiles and planes carry people from one place to the other. The earth rotates once every twenty-four hours and revolves round the sun once in a year. The sun itself is in motion in the Milky Way, which is again moving within its local group of galaxies. Motion is change in position of an object with time.

questions.question: What is the definition of motion?
questions.answer: Motion is defined as the change in position of an object with respect to time.

questions.question: Give three examples of motion from everyday life.
questions.answer: Examples include: walking and running, blood flowing in arteries and veins, leaves falling from trees, and water flowing down a dam.

questions.question: What type of motion does the Earth exhibit?
questions.answer: The Earth exhibits two types of motion: rotation about its axis once every 24 hours and revolution around the Sun once every year.

questions.question: What is rectilinear motion?
questions.answer: Rectilinear motion is the motion of objects along a straight line.

questions.question: When can we treat objects as point objects in motion?
questions.answer: Objects can be treated as point objects when their size is much smaller than the distance they move in a reasonable duration of time.

questions.question: What is Kinematics?
questions.answer: Kinematics is the study of ways to describe motion without considering the causes of motion.

topics.name: INSTANTANEOUS VELOCITY AND SPEED
topics.context: Instantaneous velocity is a fundamental concept in motion that describes the velocity of an object at a specific instant of time. It differs from average velocity which measures the overall rate of position change over a time interval.

questions.question: What is instantaneous velocity?
questions.answer: Instantaneous velocity is the velocity of an object at a specific instant of time, defined as the limit of average velocity as the time interval approaches zero.

questions.question: How does instantaneous velocity differ from average velocity?
questions.answer: Instantaneous velocity represents the velocity at a specific moment, while average velocity represents the overall rate of displacement over a finite time interval.

questions.question: What is the relationship between speed and velocity?
questions.answer: Speed is the magnitude of velocity. While velocity is a vector quantity having both magnitude and direction, speed is a scalar quantity having only magnitude.

questions.question: Can instantaneous speed be different from the magnitude of instantaneous velocity?
questions.answer: No, instantaneous speed is always equal to the magnitude of instantaneous velocity at any given instant.

questions.question: What are the SI units of velocity and speed?
questions.answer: Both velocity and speed are measured in meters per second (m/s) in the SI system.

questions.question: When is instantaneous velocity zero?
questions.answer: Instantaneous velocity is zero at the moment when an object is momentarily at rest, such as at the highest point of a vertically thrown object.

topics.name: ACCELERATION
topics.context: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. It describes how quickly the velocity of an object changes.

questions.question: What is acceleration?
questions.answer: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. It measures how quickly an object's velocity changes.

questions.question: What are the SI units of acceleration?
questions.answer: The SI unit of acceleration is meters per second squared (m/s²).

questions.question: Can an object have constant speed but still be accelerating?
questions.answer: Yes, if an object is moving in a circular path at constant speed, it is still accelerating because its velocity (which includes direction) is constantly changing.

questions.question: What is deceleration?
questions.answer: Deceleration is negative acceleration, where the velocity decreases with time.

questions.question: What is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
questions.answer: The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 m/s² downward.

questions.question: When is acceleration zero?
questions.answer: Acceleration is zero when an object moves with constant velocity (both constant speed and direction).

topics.name: KINEMATIC EQUATIONS FOR UNIFORMLY ACCELERATED MOTION
topics.context: Kinematic equations describe the motion of objects under constant acceleration. These equations relate displacement, initial velocity, final velocity, acceleration, and time.

questions.question: What are the three basic kinematic equations for uniform acceleration?
questions.answer:
1) v = u + at
2) s = ut + (1/2)at²
3) v² = u² + 2as
where v is final velocity, u is initial velocity, a is acceleration, t is time, and s is displacement.

questions.question: When can these equations be used?
questions.answer: These equations can only be used when acceleration is constant throughout the motion.

questions.question: What is the significance of the equation v = u + at?
questions.answer: This equation shows that velocity changes linearly with time under constant acceleration.

questions.question: How is the equation s = ut + (1/2)at² derived?
questions.answer: This equation is derived by integrating the velocity-time equation and represents the displacement as a function of time under constant acceleration.

questions.question: What does v² = u² + 2as tell us?
questions.answer: This equation relates final and initial velocities to displacement and acceleration, without explicitly involving time.

questions.question: Why are these equations important in physics?
questions.answer: These equations are fundamental tools for solving problems involving motion under constant acceleration, such as free fall and projectile motion.

topics.name: RELATIVE VELOCITY
topics.context: Relative velocity is the velocity of an object as observed from another object or reference frame that may itself be moving.

questions.question: What is relative velocity?
questions.answer: Relative velocity is the velocity of an object as measured from a reference frame that may itself be in motion.

questions.question: How do you find relative velocity between two objects?
questions.answer: Relative velocity is found by vector subtraction of the velocities: v₁₂ = v₁ - v₂, where v₁₂ is the velocity of object 1 relative to object 2.

questions.question: Why is relative velocity important?
questions.answer: Relative velocity is important because motion is always measured relative to some reference frame, and different observers in different reference frames may measure different velocities for the same object.

questions.question: Give an example of relative velocity in everyday life.
questions.answer: A passenger walking in a moving train: their velocity relative to the train is different from their velocity relative to the ground.

questions.question: Does relative velocity affect collision speeds?
questions.answer: Yes, the impact speed in a collision depends on the relative velocity between the colliding objects, not their individual velocities relative to the ground.

questions.question: How does relative velocity relate to frame of reference?
questions.answer: Relative velocity demonstrates that motion is frame-dependent - the same motion can be described differently by observers in different reference frames.
